title_en: Pacific Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter 2018-2025
title_de: Pacific Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter 2018-2025
source_en: Pacific Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter endorsed by heads of state at the Pacific Islands Forum 2019
quote_en: Pacific Regional Marine Litter Action Plan – Implementation Activities: 1. Building a Policy and Regulatory Framework: 1.1 Support the development of a global legal framework to address marine litter and microplastics.

source_en: National Statement at the Fourth Session of United Nations Environment Assembly 2019, by Dr. Mehmet Emin Birpinar, Vice-Minister Of Environment And Urbanization
quote_en: Unfortunately, existing programmes and measures are not sufficient to efficiently reduce marine litter and microplastics. Thats why we strongly urge the UN to formulate a new solution-oriented and sound international agreement on this issue. I would like to state that Turkey is ready to provide the utmost support for such an initiative.

source_en: Nordic Ministerial Declaration
quote_en: We, the Nordic Ministers of Environment and Climate: [...] 8. Call for the development of a global agreement to more effectively and comprehensively deal with the issue of marine plastic litter and microplastics on a global level in an integrated manner.

source_en: St. John's declaration adopted by the The Fortieth Regular Meeting of the Conference of Heads of Government of the Caribbean Community (CARICOM), July 2019
quote_en: Heads of Government: [...] 14. Underscore the urgent need for a global agreement to address plastics and microplastic pollution and in this regard recall resolution 3/7 of the United Nations Environment Assembly, held in Kenya in March 2019 and the long-term ambition to eliminate discharges of litter and microplastics to the oceans.

title_en: African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN)
title_de: African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN)
source_en: African Ministerial Congress on the Environment (AMCEN). Durban Declaration on taking action for environmental sustainability and prosperity in Africa
quote_en: We[, African ministers for the environment,] commit ourselves to supporting global action to address plastic pollution, which will require further work in order to engage more effectively on global governance matters relating to plastic pollution, including reinforcing existing agreements and the option of a new global agreement on plastic pollution that takes a comprehensive approach to addressing the full life cycle of plastics, from production and design to waste prevention and management, while ensuring coherence among and coordination of activities undertaken by existing regional and international instruments and taking into consideration national circumstances while highlighting the importance of technology transfer, research on alternatives to plastic and adequate financing to enable African countries to deal with plastic pollution.

title_en: EU Council Conclusions on Oceans and Seas
title_de: EU Council Conclusions on Oceans and Seas
source_en: EU Council Conclusions on Oceans and Seas
quote_en: The Council of the European Union, [...] 45. STRESSES the importance of stepping up global actions for preventing the leakage of plastic litter and other harmful substances into the environment, and in particular the oceans, including through the consideration of an international agreement to address plastic pollution, in particular marine plastics pollution.

title_en: 3rd Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Bamako Convention
title_de: 3rd Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Bamako Convention
source_en: Decision 3/8, para. 6 of the third meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Bamako Convention
quote_en: The Conference of the Parties [...] decides [...] 6. To call for a new legally binding global agreement to combat plastic pollution, covering the full life cycle of plastics, with a view to reducing both the quantity and the harmful qualities of plastic wastes, highlighting the elimination of the trade, production and use of single-use plastics and the substitution and re-design of such products, while emphasizing the importance of technology research and transfer, and the need for adequate financing to enable African countries to prevent plastic pollution

title_en: India – Norway Joint Statement on Climate and Environment
title_de: India – Norway Joint Statement on Climate and Environment
source_en: India – Norway Joint Statement on Climate and Environment
quote_en: The Ministers emphasized a shared understanding of the global and urgent nature of marine plastic litter and microplastics and underlined that this issue cannot be solved by any one country alone. They are committed to supporting global action to address plastic pollution and exploring the feasibility of establishing a new global agreement on plastic pollution.

title_en: Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
title_de: Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
source_en: Founding member of Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
quote_en: Some specific objectives [of the Group of Friends] include: [...] 3. To support the process to explore global response options, including a new global agreement.

source_en: Ministerial statement at the launch of the Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
quote_en: We need to set the direction for a new global framework to fight marine plastic pollution.

title_en: Statement by Permanent Representative of Bangladesh to the UN in New York
title_de: Statement by Permanent Representative of Bangladesh to the UN in New York
source_en: Statement by Permanent Representative to the UN in New York at the launch of the Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
quote_en: Binding global commitments and matching resources and actions at every level is urgently required.

title_en: Statement by Permanent Representative of Germany to the UN in New York
title_de: Statement by Permanent Representative of Germany to the UN in New York
source_en: Statement by Permanent Representative to the UN in New York at the launch of the Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
quote_en: We need to close current gaps in our international response. A binding international agreement on plastic waste would, in Germany’s view, help in addressing this.

title_en: Statement by Permanent Representative of the Philippines to the UN in New York
title_de: Statement by Permanent Representative of the Philippines to the UN in New York
source_en: Statement by Permanent Representative to the UN in New York at the launch of the Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
quote_en: The Philippines continues to espouse the commencement of a negotiation of a new treaty to combat marine plastic pollution, consistent with our position at UNEA4. We support the adoption of a negotiations mandate at UNEA 5 in 2021. This binding agreement must commit governments to address marine plastic pollution.

title_en: Statement by Permanent Representative of Sri Lanka to the UN in New York
title_de: Statement by Permanent Representative of Sri Lanka to the UN in New York
source_en: Statement by Permanent Representative to the UN in New York at the launch of the Group of Friends to Combat Marine Plastic Pollution
quote_en: It is now imperative for the global body [UN] as a whole to adopt binding obligations to combat the abhorrent practice of marine plastic pollution.

source_en: Ministerial Declaration, 'Our Baltic' Conference
quote_en: We[,Ministers of Environment, Maritime Economy, Agriculture and Fisheries of Baltic Sea Member States and of the Commissioner for ‘Environment, Oceans and Fisheries’,] COMMIT to promote and actively work for a global agreement to reduce and prevent plastic marine litter and micro plastics

title_en: Statement by Environment Minister of Rwanda at UN Biodiversity Summit
title_de: Statement by Environment Minister of Rwanda at UN Biodiversity Summit
source_en: Pre-recorded statement by Ms Jeanne d'Arc Mujawamariya, Environment Minister
quote_en: Rwanda is committed to stop plastic pollution, but believes that this requires a global solution. We therefore support the establishment of a new global agreement to combat plastic pollution.

title_en: Statement by Environment Minister of Peru
title_de: Statement by Environment Minister of Peru
source_en: Statement by Environment Minister of Peru, Kirla Echegaray, at the launch of the Nordic Report on possible elements of a new treaty, 19 Oct 2020
quote_en: As environment minister of the Republic of Peru, I want to begin this speech by confirming the commitment of my country to promote a comprehensive management of plastic waste with a circular economy approach, as well as to promote a global agreement on this issue.

source_en: EU Council Conclusions on Biodiversity
quote_en: The Council of the European Union, [...] 47. COMMITS to work towards a global agreement to reduce plastic marine litter;

title_en: Statement by Environment Minister of the United Kingdom
title_de: Statement by Environment Minister of the United Kingdom
source_en: Statement by Environment Minister of the United Kingdom, Zac Goldsmith, at a WTO event on trade and the enviroment, 18 Nov 2020
quote_en: We believe it is time to start negotiating a new global agreement to coordinate action on marine plastic litter and microplastic litter, one that goes far beyond the existing framework.

title_en: Statement by Special Assistant to the Minister of Environment of Ghana
title_de: Statement by Special Assistant to the Minister of Environment of Ghana
source_en: Statement by Special Assistant to the Minister of Environment, Oliver Boachie, WCEFonline Panel Discussion, GPAP Ghana circular economy event, 24 Nov 2020
quote_en: The NPAP platform has provided us a unique opportunity for Ghana to showcase what we are doing in the country to support the global effort to confront the menace of plastics in a sustainable way. We intend to use this platform to lend Ghana’s support for a Global Agreement to end plastic waste.

title_en: Statement by Deputy Minisiter of Environment of Viet Nam
title_de: Statement by Deputy Minisiter of Environment of Viet Nam
source_en: Statement by Deputy Minisiter of Environment, Le Minh Ngan, at High-level panel session at SEA of Solutions 2020, 29 Nov 2020
quote_en: Vietnam affirms its support and willingness to participate in the formulation of a global agreement on marine plastic waste.

title_en: Statement by Principal Secretary, Ministry of Environment and Forestry of Kenya
title_de: Statement by Principal Secretary, Ministry of Environment and Forestry of Kenya
source_en: Statement by Chris Kiptoo, Principal Secretary, Ministry of Environment and Forestry, Kenya, at Ocean Action for Sustainability high-level event, 17 February 2021
quote_en: Smuggling of [plastic] bags from neighbouring countries has been a challenge. This increases cost of enforcement, and could better be addressed by all countries committing to implement a global agreement on plastics, including adoption of common standards.

title_en: Statement by the Russion Federation at UNEA 5.1
title_de: Statement by the Russion Federation at UNEA 5.1
source_en: Statement by H.E. Mr. Dmitry Maksimychev, Ambassador of the Russian Federation to the Republic of Kenya and Permanent Representative to International Organizations in Nairobi
quote_en: We welcome the outcome of the work of the Expert group on pollution of the marine environment by micro plastic and support its recommendation of launching an intergovermental negotiation  prosess to elaborate a new international agreement in this field.

source_en: Statement by H.E. Mrs Annett Günther, Ambassador of the Federal Republic of Germany to Kenya, Adjournment Plenary, UNEA 5.1, 23 Feb 2021
quote_en: In this context, Ghana, Ecuador and Germany decided to join forces to keep the topic of marine litter and plastic pollution high on the political agenda towards UNEA 5.2. It is our strong belief that several countries from all regions of the world are ready to do the next decisive step towards a new global agreement. Ghana, Ecuador and Germany want to foster this process by hosting a dedicated international ministerial conference on marine litter and plastic pollution towards the end of the third quarter of this year.

source_en: National Plastics Plan 2021, Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment, 2021
quote_en: Australia will pursue improved coordinated global action to address marine plastic pollution including through discussions towards a new global agreement at the United Nations Environment Assembly.

title_en: G7 Climate and Environment Ministers' Meeting Communiqué
title_de: G7 Climate and Environment Ministers' Meeting Communiqué
source_en: G7 Climate and Environment Ministers' Meeting Communiqué, para. 72
quote_en: Recognising the scale, urgency and transboundary nature of the global action needed to tackle marine plastic litter and microplastics, including by considering a life-cycle approach, we welcome the work of the ad hoc open-ended expert group (AHEG) established by UNEA resolution 3/7 and extended by UNEA resolution 4/6 towards UNEA 5.2, and will fully engage in discussions or negotiations on the options identified, with the aim of taking a step forward on that occasion on suggested options which include strengthening existing instruments, a potential new global instrument, and multi-stakeholder engagement.

title_en: Canada's Participation in G7 Climate and Environment Ministers’ Meeting
title_de: Canada's Participation in G7 Climate and Environment Ministers’ Meeting
source_en: Press Release on Canada's Participation in G7 Climate and Environment Ministers’ Meeting 2021
quote_en: Canada [...] emphasized that more partnerships and investments are needed to address marine plastic litter. This is why Canada is participating in the important work under way through the United Nations Environment Assembly and is supportive of beginning negotiations towards a new global agreement on plastics.

source_en: Ocean Day Plastic Pollution Declaration presented at the UN High-Level Debate on the Ocean, June 1st, 2021
quote_en: We [representatives of States endorsing the Declaration] commit to work for a decision at UNEA5.2 to establish an Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee recommending starting negotiations of a global legally binding agreement to combat plastic pollution, with the aim of concluding this as soon as possible.

title_en: Statement by the Environment Minister of New Zealand
title_de: Statement by the Environment Minister of New Zealand
source_en: Press Release by the office of the Environment Minister Hon David Parker
quote_en: Minister Parker said addressing the plastics problem also requires action across borders. [...] “We want to be part of global solutions to tackle the impacts of plastic pollution. New Zealand supports coordinated global action through discussions towards a new global agreement at the United Nations Environment Assembly in 2022,” David Parker said.

title_en: Statement by Minister of the Environment of Japan
title_de: Statement by Minister of the Environment of Japan
source_en: Statement by KOIZUMI Shinjiro, Minister of the Environment, Japan, at G20 Environment Ministers' Meeting (July 22, 2021)
quote_en: And as initiatives for the future, Japan shifts the position from neutral to support for the establishment of an Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee (INC) to discuss a new global instrument at UNEA5.2 planned in February next year. The Committee should include as wide participation as possible.

title_en: Ministerial Statement at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Ministerial Statement at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Ministerial Statement at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution (hybrid in Geneva and online), 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: We [endorsers of the statement] recognize the need for urgent action and affirm our commitment to take the next decisive steps by working towards the timely establishment of an Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution at UNEA-5.2, with the aim of achieving a new Global Agreement with ambitious goals, wide participation and means of implementation.

title_en: Statement by Argentina at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Statement by Argentina at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Statement by Vice Minister of Environment, Federovisky Sergio, at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution, 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: Argentina supports, like many others, kicking off negotiations towards a global agreement that addresses the problem of plastic pollution in a holistic fashion. This framework, amongst others, will allow for cooperation and international assistance and will allow for the involvement of all relevant stakeholders, because to find solutions together, we must work towards consensus and cooperation of all is a must.

title_en: Statement by Indonesia at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Statement by Indonesia at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Statement by Minister of Environment and Forestry, H.E. Siti Nurbaya Bakar, at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution, 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: Marine litter and plastic pollution are multi-dimensional in nature, requiring us to move beyond business-as-usual and pursue more robust global efforts. I appreciate the suggestion to start negotiating a global agreement on marine litter and plastic pollution at UNEA 5.2. [...]  Let me conclude by reconfirming Indonesia's commitment to scale up the global commitment to addressing plastic pollution. [...] It is imperative that we gather as much support as possible to have a truly effective and rigorous global framework agreement on marine litter and plastic pollution.

title_en: Statement by Brazil at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Statement by Brazil at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Statement by the Second Secretary, Permanent Mission Of Brazil To The United Nations In Geneva, at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution, 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: Brazil considers plastic pollution a critical environmental challenge which requires an international response. Therefore, we're committed to contribute to the debate, and appreciate the initiative to discuss a draft declaration on the matter. Brazil also deems essential the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities being included in the declaration, as part of the driving principles to reduce marine plastic waste […]. Cognisant of the negative impacts of plastic pollution, Brazil agrees with the negotiation of a global agreement, based on a clear and common vision.

title_en: Statement by Yemen at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Statement by Yemen at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Statement by Minister of Water and Environment, H.E. Taofeg Abdulwahd Ali AL-SHARJABI, at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution, 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: The Republic of Yemen expresses its concerns, given the severity of marine litter and plastic pollution. We, alongside other states, hope to see the creation of an Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee which would see participation by all so it’s to achieve the stated goals.

title_en: Statement by Eritrea at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Statement by Eritrea at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Statement by Permanent Representative of Eritrea to the United Nations in Geneva, at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution, 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: Efforts made by individual countries have not achieved the desired results. It is high time to commence negotiations towards a binding global agreement on plastic.

title_en: Statement by Guatemala at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
title_de: Statement by Guatemala at Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution
source_en: Statement by Guatemala at the Ministerial Conference on Marine Litter and Plastic Pollution, 1 & 2 September 2021
quote_en: As a lot of plastics end up in the ocean, we need an international treaty on marine litter. [Countries] will be coming up with a binding agreement so as to enshrine commitments and policies, programs and plans with a view to curbing this kind of pollution.

title_en: Draft Resolution by Peru and Rwanda
source_en: Draft Resolution on an internationally legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, proposed by Peru and Rwanda
quote_en: The United Nations Environment Assembly may wish to consider the adoption of the draft resolution on an internationally legally binding instrument on plastic pollution: [...] Requests the Executive Director to convene  an intergovernmental  negotiating committee under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Assembly with the mandate to prepare an international legally binding instrument to address plastic pollution, commencing its work in 2022 with the goal of completing by the sixth session of the Environment Assembly. [...]

title_en: African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN)
title_de: African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN)
source_en: Report of the ministerial segment of the eighteenth session of the African Ministerial Conference on the Environment
quote_en: We, African ministers for the environment, [...] will work towards having a new global legally binding agreement on marine litter and plastic pollution that takes a comprehensive approach to address the full lifecycle of plastics, from production and design to waste prevention and management, while ensuring coherence and coordination of activities undertaken by existing regional and international instruments, and create a supporting structure for implementation in developing countries, as well as taking into account the gap between developing and developed countries in terms of scientific knowledge, capacity, technological advances, technical and financial support in the fight against marine waste and plastic pollution; [...]  support the draft resolution on marine litter and plastic pollution, presented by Rwanda and supported by other countries; [...]  agree to develop a common Africa regional approach on engagement on the proposed draft resolution on marine litter and plastics pollution.

title_en: Statement by The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken during his visit in Kenya
title_de: Statement by The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken during his visit in Kenya
source_en: Statement by The US Secretary of State Antony Blinken during his visit in Kenya, 18 November 2021
quote_en: We [the United States ] are stepping up our efforts to tackle another pollutant that threatens our planet – plastic – by announcing the United States' support for multilateral negotiations on a global agreement to combat ocean plastic pollution by launching negotiations at the UN Environment Assembly in February 2022. Our goal is to create a tool that we can use to protect our oceans, and all the life that they sustain, from growing global harms of plastic pollution.

source_en: Ministerial Session of the 22nd Meeting of the Contracting Parties to the Convention for the Protection of the Marine Environment and the Coastal Region of the Mediterranean and its Protocols
quote_en: We, Ministers of the Environment and Heads of Delegation of the Contracting Parties to the Barcelona Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment and the Coastal Region of the Mediterranean (Barcelona Convention) and its Protocols [...] commit to [...] enhance action in synergy with other relevant regional and global initiatives, in particular for the establishment of an International Negotiating Committee at UNEA 5.2 , with a mandate to develop a legally binding global agreement to address plastic pollution, to prevent and reduce marine litter, including micro-plastics, and their harmful effects [...]

title_en: Ministerial Statement on Plastic Pollution and Environmentally Sustainable Plastics Trade
title_de: Ministerial Statement on Plastic Pollution and Environmentally Sustainable Plastics Trade
source_en: Ministerial Statement on Plastic Pollution qnd Environmentally Sustainable Plastics Trade, WTO's Informal Dialogue on Plastic Pollution and Environmentally Sustainable Plastics Trade (IDP), 10 December 2021
quote_en: We, [ Ministers representing the Members of the WTO who issue the statement ] emphasize the importance of continuing to engage and support actions in other international processes, including: Enhancing cooperation with other international organizations in areas such as definitions, scope, standards, design and labelling for plastics (including plastic packaging) and capacity building that would promote a more environmentally sustainable plastics sector, including through relevant international processes, and intensifying our work and continued cooperation on areas of common interest, such as the ongoing discussions towards a new global instrument on plastics at UNEA-5, the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and the Basel Convention.

title_en: Draft Resolution by Peru and Rwanda
source_en: Draft Resolution on an internationally legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, proposed by Peru and Rwanda, updated on January 10, 2022, published at the Committee of Permanent Representatives Subcommittee meeting on 18 January 2022
quote_en: The United Nations Environment Assembly may wish to consider the adoption of the draft resolution on an internationally legally binding instrument on plastic pollution: [...] Requests the Executive Director to convene  an intergovernmental  negotiating committee under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Assembly with the mandate to prepare an international legally binding instrument to address plastic pollution, commencing its work in 2022 with the goal of completing by the sixth session of the Environment Assembly; [...]

title_en: Statement by G77 and China at the 157th Meeting of the Committee of Permanent Representatives
title_de: Statement by G77 and China at the 157th Meeting of the Committee of Permanent Representatives
source_en: Statement by the Group of 77 and China at the 157th Meeting of the Committee of Permanent Representatives on 01 February 2022
quote_en: [...] The G-77 and China welcomes the discussions regarding the need to tackle the global plastic pollution and affirm our commitment to address this important issue at this UNEA-5.2, with the aim to initiate negotiations to achieve a new Global Agreement on Plastic Pollution with ambitious goals and equally ambitious means of implementation, and wide participation.

title_en: Updated list of Co-Sponsors of the Draft Resolution by Peru and Rwanda
title_de: Updated list of Co-Sponsors of the Draft Resolution by Peru and Rwanda
source_en: Updated list of Co-Sponsors of the Draft Resolution on an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, proposed by Peru and Rwanda, 14 February 2022
quote_en:
Draft resolution on an Internationally Legally binding Instrument on Plastic Pollution submitted by Peru and Rwanda
[...]
Co-sponsors: Azerbaijan, Benin, Bosnia And Herzegovina, Cabo Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, European Union And Its Member States, Gabon, Georgia, Guinea, Iceland, Iran, Kenya, Madagascar, Mauritius, Norway, North Macedonia, Philippines, Republic Of Korea, Senegal, Seychelles, Switzerland, Timor-Leste, Uganda, United Kingdom, Uruguay, Islamic Republic Of Pakistan.

title_en: UNEA-5.2 Resolution 'End Plastic Pollution: Toward an International Legally Binding Instrument'
title_de: UNEA-5.2 Resolution 'End Plastic Pollution: Toward an International Legally Binding Instrument'
source_en: UNEA-5.2 Outcome: Adoption of the Resolution 'End Plastic Pollution: Toward an International Legally Binding Instrument'

title_en: High Ambition Coalition Joint Ministerial Statement at INC-2
title_de: High Ambition Coalition Joint Ministerial Statement at INC-2
source_en: High Ambition Coalition Joint Ministerial Statement at INC-2, 26 May 2023
quote_en:
We, the Ministers of the High Ambition Coalition,
[...]
Call for binding provisions in the treaty to eliminate and restrict unnecessary, avoidable, or problematic plastics, as well as the plastic polymers, chemical constituents and plastic products that are of particular concern  [...]
Call for binding provisions in the treaty to increase the safe circularity of plastics in the economy [...] and call for parties to commit to targets in key areas, such as on reduction, repairability, environmentally sound and safe recyclability and reuse, refill systems, and the use of recycled content. [...]
Call for binding provisions in the treaty to prevent plastic waste in the first place and if avoidance is not possible, to manage plastic waste in an environmentally sound and safe manner, consistent with other international instruments. [...]
Call for binding provisions in the treaty to eliminate the release of plastics, including microplastics, to air, water (both inland and marine) and land, and measures to address specific sources of plastic pollution, including but not limited to microplastics intentionally added in products, the release of plastic pellets and loss of fishing gear, building on other international instruments. [...]
Call for binding provisions in the treaty for the mobilisation of the means of implementation from all sources that are necessary to deliver action on the ground [...]
Call for provisions to remediate existing plastic pollution, recognizing its disproportionate negative socio-economic and environmental consequences in developing countries, in an environmentally sound manner and in accordance with scientific and evidence-based social, economic and environmental impact assessments and national circumstances [...].

title_en: High Ambition Coalition Member States Ministerial Joint Statement INC-3
source_en: High Ambition Coalition Member States Ministerial Joint Statement prior to INC-3
quote_en: "[...] we the 60 Ministers of the High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution: [...] Reiterate our call for binding provisions in the treaty to restrain and reduce the consumption and production of primary plastic polymers to sustainable levels; eliminate and restrict unnecessary, avoidable, or problematic plastics, as well as the plastic polymers, chemical constituents and plastic products that are of particular concern due to their adverse effects on the environment and human health; increase the safe circularity of plastics in the economy, guided by the waste hierarchy; manage plastic waste in an environmentally sound and safe manner, and eliminate the release of plastics, including microplastics, to air, water and land. Continue to call for binding provisions in the treaty to ensure reporting and transparency across the value chain of plastics as well as for the mobilization of the means of implementation from all sources that are necessary to deliver action on the ground to end plastic pollution."
